content: The **expressways of Singapore** are a system of [controlled-access highways](/wiki/Controlled-access_highway) in Singapore that allow motorists to travel quickly from one urban area to another. Construction of the system was authorised when construction of the [Pan Island Expressway](/wiki/Pan_Island_Expressway) began in 1962. They usually have three to four [lanes](/wiki/Lane) in each direction, although there are two-lane carriageways at many expressway intersections and five-lane carriageways in some places. There are currently ten expressways and studies about the feasibility of more are ongoing. Construction on the first expressway, the [Pan Island Expressway](/wiki/Pan_Island_Expressway), started in 1966. As of 2014[update], there are 163 kilometres (101 mi) of expressways in Singapore. The Singaporean expressway networks are connected with [Malaysian expressway networks](/wiki/Malaysian_Expressway_System) via the [Ayer Rajah Expressway](/wiki/Ayer_Rajah_Expressway) (connects with the [Second Link Expressway](/wiki/Second_Link_Expressway) via the [Malaysia-Singapore Second Link](/wiki/Malaysia%E2%80%93Singapore_Second_Link) bridge) and the [Bukit Timah Expressway](/wiki/Bukit_Timah_Expressway) (connects with the [Johor Bahru Eastern Dispersal Link Expressway](/wiki/Johor_Bahru_Eastern_Dispersal_Link_Expressway) via [Johor–Singapore Causeway](/wiki/Johor%E2%80%93Singapore_Causeway)). ## History Chronology of major events DateEventsRemarks15 April 1962Construction of the [Pan Island Expressway](/wiki/Pan_Island_Expressway) (PIE) begins.Construction during full internal self-government of Singapore8 May 1966First phase of the [Pan Island Expressway](/wiki/Pan_Island_Expressway) (PIE) completed. Construction of the second phase of the PIE begins. SLE2 January 1998Opening of the [Ayer Rajah Expressway](/wiki/Ayer_Rajah_Expressway) (AYE) phase 2.Jurong Town Hall Road - Tuas Second Link22 February 1998Opening of the [Seletar Expressway](/wiki/Seletar_Expressway) (SLE) phase 2.Length: 10.8 kilometres Woodlands Avenue 2 - Upper Thomson Road Opened by: Mr John Chen Seow Phun, Minister of State for Communications 22 August 1998Opening of the [Tampines Expressway](/wiki/Tampines_Expressway) viaduct connecting PIE and TPE.September 1998The [Electronic Road Pricing](/wiki/Electronic_Road_Pricing) (ERP) systems is implemented on all expressways.2001Construction of the [Kallang-Paya Lebar Expressway](/wiki/Kallang-Paya_Lebar_Expressway) begins.2004The SOS telephones were removed on all expressways except for tunnels.23 June 2007Opening of the Tampines Service Road, currently part of the [Kallang-Paya Lebar Expressway](/wiki/Kallang-Paya_Lebar_Expressway) (KPE).26 October 2007Opening of the [Kallang–Paya Lebar Expressway](/wiki/Kallang%E2%80%93Paya_Lebar_Expressway) (KPE), the longest [subterranean](/wiki/Subterranea_(geography)) road tunnel in [Southeast Asia](/wiki/Southeast_Asia).ECP - PIEMarch 2008Construction of the [Marina Coastal Expressway](/wiki/Marina_Coastal_Expressway) (MCE) begins.20 September 2008Official opening of the [Kallang-Paya Lebar Expressway](/wiki/Kallang-Paya_Lebar_Expressway) (KPE).Prime Minister [Lee Hsien Loong](/wiki/Lee_Hsien_Loong) PIE - TPE29 December 2013Opening of the [Marina Coastal Expressway](/wiki/Marina_Coastal_Expressway) (MCE), [Singapore](/wiki/Singapore)'s first undersea expressway.Length: 5 kilometres The [East Coast Parkway](/wiki/East_Coast_Parkway) was shortened to Sheares Avenue. ## Expansion The latest expressway completed is the 5 km [Marina Coastal Expressway](/wiki/Marina_Coastal_Expressway) (MCE), which links the [East Coast Parkway](/wiki/East_Coast_Parkway) and Kallang-Paya Lebar Expressway to [Marina South](/wiki/Marina_South) and [Ayer Rajah Expressway](/wiki/Ayer_Rajah_Expressway) and includes Singapore's first undersea tunnel. Construction started in 2008 and the expressway opened to traffic 29 December 2013. Prior to construction of the Marina Coastal Expressway, the [Kallang–Paya Lebar Expressway](/wiki/Kallang%E2%80%93Paya_Lebar_Expressway) which runs for 12 km, 9 km of which are 10 metres underground, was started in 2001 and a 3 km section linking the [Pan Island Expressway](/wiki/Pan_Island_Expressway) and [East Coast Parkway](/wiki/East_Coast_Parkway) was opened in late 2007. The Kallang–Paya Lebar Expressway was completed on 20 September 2008. Construction of the 11th expressway, the [North–South Corridor](/wiki/North%E2%80%93South_Corridor,_Singapore), originally conceptualised as the North-South Expressway, was announced on 30 January 2008. The new 21.5-kilometre expressway will cost about S$7.47 billion when fully completed by 2029 and will connect the [East Coast Parkway](/wiki/East_Coast_Parkway) with the northern parts of Singapore. In 2016, the [Land Transport Authority](/wiki/Land_Transport_Authority) announced that the [North–South Corridor](/wiki/North%E2%80%93South_Corridor,_Singapore) will be Singapore’s first integrated transport corridor featuring continuous bus lanes and cycling trunk routes, rather than a normal expressway when originally conceptualised. ## Features Like all other global [controlled-access expressway](/wiki/Controlled-access_highway) network, there are no traffic lights on the expressways. At an [interchange](/wiki/Interchange_(road)) with another road, an expressway is connected to it via slip roads. This allows traffic to change routes without having to stop or slow down. Due to the need to conserve space in land-scarce Singapore, there are no [cloverleaf interchanges](/wiki/Cloverleaf_interchange) on the entire island as they are too large. Instead, traffic efficiency and land space are maximised by having traffic lights on terrestrial roads, as well as the usage of interchanges such as [stack interchanges](/wiki/Stack_interchange). The most common forms of highway-road or highway-highway intersections are [single-point urban](/wiki/Single-point_urban_interchange), [diamond](/wiki/Diamond_interchange), and [trumpet interchanges](/wiki/Trumpet_interchange). Newer expressways such as the Kallang-Paya Lebar Expressway and the future North South Corridor uses on-ramps and off-ramps to conserve space even further and minimise disruption to the road system, through the construction of viaducts and tunnels. The road surface is [asphalt](/wiki/Asphalt_concrete), unlike normal roads which may have [concrete](/wiki/Concrete) surfaces. The lanes are separated with white dashed lines, while unbroken white lines are used to mark the edges of the median and [shoulder](/wiki/Shoulder_(road)). The shoulder is designated for stops in cases of breakdowns and emergencies, and driving on it is prohibited by law. Lanes are numbered from right to left, with lane 1 being the closest to the median. [Crash barriers](/wiki/Crash_barrier), [cat's eyes](/wiki/Cat%27s_eye_(road)) and [rumble strips](/wiki/Rumble_strip) are also used to ensure road safety. There are signs marking the start and end of an expressway at its entry and exit points respectively. The expressways are also assigned route codes consisting three letters that form their respective initials, making the Singaporean expressway network as the only highway system with route coding system. The [Expressway Monitoring and Advisory System](/wiki/Expressway_Monitoring_and_Advisory_System) is used on all the expressways—cameras are used for live monitoring of expressway conditions, and [LED](/wiki/LED) signboards display information messages, such as [warnings](/wiki/Warning_sign) of any disruptions to the normal flow of traffic, as well as estimated travel times. The longest expressway, the Pan Island Expressway, is only 41 km (25 mi) long and therefore has no [rest areas](/wiki/Rest_area). Singaporean expressways are the only highway network in Singapore with their own route codes. They are assigned with [three-letter codes](/wiki/Road_designation_or_abbreviation) named after their respective initials where the last letter is always E; for example, PIE for the [Pan Island Expressway](/wiki/Pan_Island_Expressway). The only exception is the [East Coast Parkway](/wiki/East_Coast_Parkway) (ECP) whose the last letter is other than E. ## Safety The default speed limit and National Speed Limits on Singapore expressways is 90 km/h (56 mph), but in certain areas a lower speed limit such as 80 km/h (50 mph) or 70 km/h (43 mph) is applied, especially in large urban areas, tunnels, heavy traffic and crosswinds. Speed traps are also deployed by the Singapore police at many places along the expressways and are deployed from 7am to 12am. Certain types of transport, such as [pedestrians](/wiki/Pedestrian), [bicycles](/wiki/Bicycle), and [learner drivers](/wiki/Driver%27s_license), are not allowed. ## List of Expressways Ranking of the Length from Longest to Shortest Rank NumberExpressway NameAbbreviationOpenedLengthExit TerminusRemarks1st[Pan Island Expressway](/wiki/Pan_Island_Expressway) [PIE](/wiki/Pan_Island_Expressway)196642.8 km (26.6 mi)[Changi Airport](/wiki/Changi_Airport), [ECP](/wiki/East_Coast_Parkway) [Tuas](/wiki/Tuas), [AYE](/wiki/Ayer_Rajah_Expressway)Longest and oldest expressway in [Singapore](/wiki/Singapore). Designated as [AH2](/wiki/AH2) from Stevens Road exit to BKE exit .2nd[Ayer Rajah Expressway](/wiki/Ayer_Rajah_Expressway) [AYE](/wiki/Ayer_Rajah_Expressway)198826.5 km (16.5 mi)[MCE](/wiki/Marina_Coastal_Expressway) [Tuas Checkpoint](/wiki/Tuas_Checkpoint), [Tuas Second Link](/wiki/Malaysia%E2%80%93Singapore_Second_Link)Directly connected to [MCE](/wiki/Marina_Coastal_Expressway). Part of [AH143](/wiki/AH143).3rd*[North–South Corridor](/wiki/North%E2%80%93South_Corridor,_Singapore)* [NSE](/wiki/North%E2%80%93South_Corridor,_Singapore)*2029 (planned)*21.5 km (13.4 mi)Admiralty Road West [ECP](/wiki/East_Coast_Parkway), Republic Avenue and [Nicoll Highway](/wiki/Nicoll_Highway)Construction started in 2018, and is now estimated to be complete by 2029. Directly connected to [SLE](/wiki/Seletar_Expressway).6th[Tampines Expressway](/wiki/Tampines_Expressway) [TPE](/wiki/Tampines_Expressway)198914 km (8.7 mi)[SLE](/wiki/Seletar_Expressway), [CTE](/wiki/Central_Expressway_(Singapore)) [PIE](/wiki/Pan_Island_Expressway) Upper Changi Road East7th[Kallang–Paya Lebar Expressway](/wiki/Kallang%E2%80%93Paya_Lebar_Expressway) [KPE](/wiki/Kallang%E2%80%93Paya_Lebar_Expressway)200812 km (7.5 mi)[MCE](/wiki/Marina_Coastal_Expressway), [ECP](/wiki/East_Coast_Parkway) [TPE](/wiki/Tampines_Expressway)The expressway has the longest road tunnel in Singapore. Directly connected to [MCE](/wiki/Marina_Coastal_Expressway). Part of [AH143](/wiki/AH143).8th[Seletar Expressway](/wiki/Seletar_Expressway) [SLE](/wiki/Seletar_Expressway)199010.8 km (6.7 mi)[BKE](/wiki/Bukit_Timah_Expressway), Turf Club Avenue [CTE](/wiki/Central_Expressway_(Singapore))Directly connected to [CTE](/wiki/Central_Expressway_(Singapore)).9th[Bukit Timah Expressway](/wiki/Bukit_Timah_Expressway) [BKE](/wiki/Bukit_Timah_Expressway)198610 km (6.2 mi)[PIE](/wiki/Pan_Island_Expressway) [Woodlands Checkpoint](/wiki/Woodlands_Checkpoint), [Johor–Singapore Causeway](/wiki/Johor%E2%80%93Singapore_Causeway)Part of [AH2](/wiki/AH2).10th[Kranji Expressway](/wiki/Kranji_Expressway) [KJE](/wiki/Kranji_Expressway)19948 km (5.0 mi)[BKE](/wiki/Bukit_Timah_Expressway) [PIE](/wiki/Pan_Island_Expressway)11th[Marina Coastal Expressway](/wiki/Marina_Coastal_Expressway) [MCE](/wiki/Marina_Coastal_Expressway)20135 km (3.1 mi)[AYE](/wiki/Ayer_Rajah_Expressway) Fort Road, [ECP](/wiki/East_Coast_Parkway), [KPE](/wiki/Kallang%E2%80%93Paya_Lebar_Expressway)Singapore's first undersea expressway. Directly connected to [KPE](/wiki/Kallang%E2%80%93Paya_Lebar_Expressway) and [AYE](/wiki/Ayer_Rajah_Expressway). Part of [AH143](/wiki/AH143). ## Semi-expressways Singapore also has five semi-expressways: [Bukit Timah Road](/wiki/Bukit_Timah_Road), [Jurong Island Highway](/wiki/Jurong_Island_Highway), [Nicoll Highway](/wiki/Nicoll_Highway), the [Outer Ring Road System](/wiki/Outer_Ring_Road_System) (ORRS) and [West Coast Highway](/wiki/West_Coast_Highway,_Singapore). These semi-expressways are scaled down versions of expressways, without a uniform speed limit. Some sections still feature traffic light controlled junctions, such as the eastern section of the ORRS, some of Bukit Timah Road, the southern section of the Jurong Island Highway and the western sections of Nicoll Highway and West Coast Highway. However, much like with the expressways, semi-expressways allow motorists to travel quickly from one urban area to another with the use of [viaducts](/wiki/Viaduct), [overpasses](/wiki/Overpass) and [tunnels](/wiki/Tunnel). - Roads portal - Singapore portal - [Land Transport Authority](/wiki/Land_Transport_Authority) - [Ministry of Transport (Singapore)](/wiki/Ministry_of_Transport_(Singapore))
title: Expressways of Singapore
